awd_titl_txt: Earth's Electromagnetic Environment: Advancing Recent Discoveries in Auroral Plasma Radio Emission Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Above 70 miles over the ground, the near-Earth's environment (Geospace) is mostly organized by the Earth's magnetic field, which at a greater distance interacts with the solar wind (charged particles, plasma, flowing with a great speed from the Sun) and interplanetary magnetic field (extended Sun's magnetic field). Geospace is mostly populated by plasma that originates either in the atmosphere or in the solar wind. Interaction of the these two major players - magnetic fields and charged particles - takes various forms and produces many interesting electromagnetic phenomena such as aurorae (Northern and Southern lights), plasma waves, natural electromagnetic radiation and currents, etc., especially in the polar areas where this interaction is most intense and reaches close to the Earth. Studying these phenomena is important since they affect satellite instrumentation and communication, as well as important technologies such as GPS (Global Positioning System). 

A research effort previously funded by NSF and performed in Antarctica within the last few years made new discoveries related to natural electromagnetic phenomena in the polar areas. These discoveries are: (1) correlations between powerful auroral kilometric radiation observed at ~200,000 km above the Earth and analogous signals observed simultaneously at the South Pole Station; (2) discovery of radiation at a high harmonic of the electron cyclotron frequency (an important frequency at which charged particles oscillate in a magnetic field); and (3) discovery of a new type of radio emission of auroral origin. These phenomena are best observed, and in most cases can only be observed, using instruments deployed in Antarctica where a manmade electromagnetic interference is minimal.

The new research built on these discoveries will significantly advance our knowledge of the Earth's natural electromagnetic environment, which in turn has significant impact on the broader Geospace environment and space weather because of how interconnected these systems are. Furthermore, the new discoveries probed by this research represent   outstanding questions of Geospace research that have escaped scientists' attention so far. The research is a cost-effective investment that will advance the state of knowledge of the Geospace domain and provide students at Dartmouth College with an opportunity to obtain good skills and experience with experimental measurements and data analysis.

por.por_cntn:
In addition to the optical displays for which it is well-known, the Aurora Borealis ("Northern Lights") and Aurora Australis ("Southern Lights") produce radio emissions that can be detected with suitable instrumentation. The Antarctic, and South Pole in particular, is critical for observing these radio emissions because of the near absence of man-made radio interference; in certain frequency bands, natural auroral signals can be observed nowhere else except Antarctica but nowhere else. These signals provide a window on the physical conditions and processes happening within the auroral ionosphere at altitudes from 100 to 10000 kilometers. To observe these natural auroral radio signals, Dartmouth College operated several radio receivers using multiple antennas at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station. One outcome of this research involves signals received at harmonics of the electron gyrofrequency, a natural resonance frequency in the ionosphere corresponding to the frequency at which electrons gyrate around the Earth's magnetic field. The aurora produces radio waves at two, three, four and five times this frequency. Recent South Pole observations establish a distinctive pattern of occurrence of these radio signals: The lowest frequency harmonic occurs only in the darkness of winter, whereas the others occur during daytime, and as the sun rises higher in the sky, successively higher frequency harmonics appear, in a stair-step pattern. This pattern is an important clue to the underlying physics of the emissions, which depends on the density of charged particles in the ionosphere, which increases as the sun gets higher in the sky. These auroral emissions therefore provide measurements of the charged particle density, and possibly other important characteristics of the upper atmosphere, from a ground-level instrument, without requiring flying an expensive rocket or satellite. Other significant outcomes of this research include the first statistical study using modern instruments of very low frequency radio emissions called "hisslers," in which the radio frequency generated by the aurora decreases sharply over a time interval of about one second. The study confirmed some characteristics of hisslers known from early studies, but refuted others. Further outcomes included contributions to theoretical and modelling related to the harmonic radio emissions mentioned above,  and observation for the first time of the polarization of low-frequency components of a third type of radio emissions called "MF burst," which occurs during auroral activations called substorms. In addition to these and other scientific results, this project provided training to multiple undergraduate and graduate students.
